ANU AGA: Another
thing BCG suggested--

that the family should
decide whether they

would be running the business
or they want to be on the board.

You can't be executives
and be on the board.

And this was because
our previous board
had nine executive directors.

And it's OK to have
that model as long
as the company is doing well.

They don't have to be
critical and evaluate
their own performance.

But when they are
not doing well,

they could be very
subjective, and keep coming up
with excuses and reasons.

So we decided to reconstitute
the entire board.

And I don't think, at that
time, any company in India
had done that.

This meant I had to go to the
nine executive directors who

had been with the company
for years and years.

One of them had been
with the company

from the beginning
of his career,

and used to say that this was
his first and his last job.

To go to such dedicated
people and ask

them to step down
was difficult. I

had to ask the four independent
directors also to step down.

And I had to tell my
daughter and my son-in-law

to decide whether they
wanted to be on the board
or be executives.

I must say, at that time, they
were a little upset with me.

Because they felt
they were doing--

they were used to
running businesses.

And why am I giving them
this kind of a choice?
But I was firm.

And I also decided that
I'll be non-executive.

And the family decided,
finally, to be on the board
and not be executives.

These were tough
decisions to take.
